{{Short description|2022 Russia–Ukraine agreement on grain export}} {{about|the 2022 Russia–Ukraine grain agreement|the 1995 agreement by the [[International Grains Council]]|International Grains Agreement}} {{Infobox document | document_name = Initiative on the Safe Transportation of Grain and Foodstuffs from Ukrainian ports | image = Black Sea Initiative.svg | image_size = 260px | image_alt = A vector graphic showing the countries involved and the principles of the agreement | caption = | image2 = | image2_size = | image2_alt = | caption2 = | date_created = | date_presented = | date_ratified = | date_effective = {{Start date|df=yes|2022|7|22}}—present | location_of_document = [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]] | signers = {{flag|Ukraine}}

{{flag|United Nations}} | subject = Export of grain and related foodstuffs and fertilizers | purpose = | wikisource = Initiative on the Safe Transportation of Grain and Foodstuffs from Ukrainian Ports }} The '''Initiative on the Safe Transportation of Grain and Foodstuffs from Ukrainian ports''', also called the '''Black Sea Grain Initiative''',{{cite news |title=Joint Coordination Centre opens in Istanbul to facilitate safe export of commercial foodstuffs and fertilizers from Ukrainian ports |url=https://reliefweb.int/report/turkiye/joint-coordination-centre-opens-istanbul-facilitate-safe-export-commercial-foodstuffs-and-fertilizers-ukrainian-ports |access-date=31 July 2022 |work=reliefweb.int |publisher=[[United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]] |date=27 July 2022 |language=en |archive-date=31 July 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220731003627/https://reliefweb.int/report/turkiye/joint-coordination-centre-opens-istanbul-facilitate-safe-export-commercial-foodstuffs-and-fertilizers-ukrainian-ports |url-status=live }} is an agreement between [[Russia]] and [[Ukraine]] made with [[Turkey]] and the [[United Nations]] (UN) during the [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine]]. The Russian invasion of Ukraine in February led to a complete halt of maritime grain shipments from Ukraine, previously a [[Economy of Ukraine#Agriculture|major exporter]] via the Black Sea. This resulted in a rise in world food prices and the threat of famine in lower-income countries. To address the issue, discussions began in April, hosted by Turkey (which [[Montreaux Convention|controls]] the [[Turkish straits|maritime routes from the Black Sea]]) and supported by the UN. The resulting agreement was signed in [[Istanbul]] on 22 July 2022, valid for a period of 120 days. The July agreement created procedures to safely export grain from certain ports to attempt to address the [[2022 food crises|2022 food crisis]]. A joint coordination and inspection center was set up in Turkey, with the UN serving as [[Secretariat (administrative office)|secretariat]]. The original agreement was set to expire on 19 November 2022. Russia suspended its participation in the agreement for several days due to a drone attack on Russian naval ships elsewhere in the Black Sea, but rejoined following mediation.{{Cite news |date=2022-11-02 |title=Russia returns to Black Sea grain deal in sudden U-turn |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/russia-resume-participation-black-sea-grain-deal-defence-ministry-2022-11-02/ |url-status=live |access-date=2022-11-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221102111743/https://www.reuters.com/world/russia-resume-participation-black-sea-grain-deal-defence-ministry-2022-11-02/ |archive-date=2022-11-02}} On 17 November 2022, the UN and Ukraine announced that the agreement had been extended for a further 120 days.{{Cite web |last= |first= |date=November 17, 2022 |title=Ukraine, UN Announce Grain Deal Extension |url=https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2022/11/17/ukraine-un-announce-grain-deal-extension-a79404 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221118024548/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2022/11/17/ukraine-un-announce-4-month-grain-deal-extension-a79404 |archive-date=November 18, 2022 |access-date=November 17, 2022 |website=[[The Moscow Times]]}} In March 2023, Turkey and the UN announced that they secured a second extension for at least another 60 days.{{Cite news |last=Erkoyun |first=Ezgi |date=5 March 2023 |title=Turkey says it is working to renew Black Sea grain deal |language=en |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/turkey-says-working-renew-black-sea-grain-deal-2023-03-05/ |access-date=2023-03-06}} In May 2023, the deal was once again extended for 60 days, expiring on 18 July.{{Cite news |last= |date=2023-05-17 |title=Russia confirms Black Sea grain deal renewed for two months |language=en |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-confirms-black-sea-grain-deal-renewed-two-months-2023-05-17/ |access-date=2023-05-17}} By mid-May 2023, more than 950 voyages had successfully left Ukrainian ports carrying over 30 million tonnes of grain and other food products to more than 40 different countries. ==Background== {{see also|2022 food crises}} In 2022, 47 million people were estimated to be suffering from severe hunger as a result of the world's soaring food costs partly due to the impact of the [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine]]. Developing and emerging countries in [[Africa]], [[Asia]], and [[Latin America]] have been impacted the most by this war due to their reliance on imported grain and fuel.{{cite web |last1=Watson |first1=Cameron |title=Metis Insights: Black Sea Grain Initiative Analysis |url=https://channel16.dryadglobal.com/metis-insights-black-sea-grain-initiative-analysis |website=channel16.dryadglobal.com |publisher=Dryad Global |access-date=31 July 2022 |language=en |date=26 July 2022 |archive-date=1 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220801135106/https://channel16.dryadglobal.com/metis-insights-black-sea-grain-initiative-analysis |url-status=live }} According to the UN [[Food and Agriculture Organization]], Ukraine is among the world's leading grain exporters, providing more than 45 million tonnes annually to the global market.{{cite news |title=Black Sea grain exports deal 'a beacon of hope' amid Ukraine war - Guterres |url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2022/07/1123062 |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=UN News |date=22 July 2022 |language=en |archive-date=1 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220801042309/https://news.un.org/en/story/2022/07/1123062 |url-status=live }} Some 20 million tonnes of grain had been held up in the Ukrainian port city of [[Odesa]], according to the [[BBC]].{{cite news |title=Food crisis: Ukraine grain export deal reached with Russia, says Turkey |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-62254597 |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=BBC News |date=22 July 2022 |archive-date=1 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220801023441/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-62254597 |url-status=live }} Almost all of Ukraine's wheat, corn, and sunflower oil were exported through its Black Sea ports prior to the conflict. Before the agreement, some ports' infrastructure has been harmed while others are under Russian control and others are blocked by mines.{{cite news |last1=Youssef |first1=Nancy |title=Mines, Port Damage Threaten Revival of Sea Route for Ukraine Grain |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/mines-port-damage-threaten-revival-of-sea-route-for-ukraine-grain-11656754200 |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=Wall Street Journal |date=2 July 2022 |archive-date=1 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220801135105/https://www.wsj.com/articles/mines-port-damage-threaten-revival-of-sea-route-for-ukraine-grain-11656754200 |url-status=live }} Initially, the Ukrainian government was reluctant to de-mine the sea due to the scale of the task and the possibility of leaving the ports open to attack.{{cite news |last1=Boffey |first1=Daniel |title=Plan to ship grain out of Ukraine dealt blow due to mines |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jun/07/plan-to-ship-grain-out-of-ukraine-dealt-blow-by-russian-sea-mines |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=the Guardian |date=7 June 2022 |language=en |archive-date=1 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220801135105/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jun/07/plan-to-ship-grain-out-of-ukraine-dealt-blow-by-russian-sea-mines |url-status=live }} ==Timeline== The ships would traverse the [[Black Sea]] in specially created corridors that are [[Demining|demined]], with Turkey inspecting all merchant vessels.{{cite news |last1=Jones |first1=Dorian |title=Agreement Signed on Trapped Ukrainian Grain |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/agreement-signed-on-trapped-ukrainian-grain/6669944.html |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=VOA |date=22 July 2022 The JCC is tasked with registering and monitoring the departure of commercial ships via satellite, internet, and other communication means. Its primary responsibility is to check for the absence of unauthorized cargo and personnel on board of the vessels.{{cite news |title=Agreement On Unblocking Grain Exports From Ukrainian Ports Signed In Istanbul |url=https://en.cfts.org.ua/news/agreement_on_unblocking_grain_exports_from_ukrainian_ports_signed_in_istanbul |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=en.cfts.org.ua |date=25 July 2022 |language=en |archive-date=5 October 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221005011517/https://en.cfts.org.ua/news/agreement_on_unblocking_grain_exports_from_ukrainian_ports_signed_in_istanbul |url-status=live }} The JCC is located on the campus of the [[National Defense University (Turkey)|National Defense University]], about seven kilometers north of the center of Istanbul. The center is headed by a Turkish admiral. A total of 20 delegates are employed (five representatives from the four involved parties each). By March 2023, Turkey and the UN announced they were facilitating negotiations for a second extension of the deal, with discussions having taken place. Russia had previously stated that it would have accepted a renewal of the deal only if its own exports were unblocked, which had been previously hampered due to Western sanctions that had indirectly affected their agricultural industry.{{Cite web |date=1 March 2023 |title=Russia says it will only renew grain deal if its own exports are unblocked |url=https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/russia-says-it-will-only-renew-grain-deal-if-its-own-exports-are-unblocked-2023-03-01/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230302193451/https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/russia-says-it-will-only-renew-grain-deal-if-its-own-exports-are-unblocked-2023-03-01/ |archive-date=2 March 2023 |access-date=16 March 2023 |website=[[Reuters]]}} Later that month, Russia had proposed to renew the deal for only 60 days, which Ukraine had refused.{{Cite web |last=Quinn |first=Aine |last2=Durisin |first2=Megan |last3=Kudrytski |first3=Aliaksandr |date=13 March 2023 |title=Ukraine Rebuffs Russia's Offer of a 60-Day Extension on Grain Deal |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-03-13/russia-open-to-60-day-extension-of-ukraine-grain-deal-tass-says |url-status=live |access-date=16 March 2023 |website=[[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]]}} However, by March 18, it was confirmed that the deal had been extended, though the UN nor Turkey had confirmed for how long. Despite this, Russia and Ukraine had both claimed the deal had been extended for 60 and 120 days, respectively.{{Cite web |last=Ritter |first=Karl |date=March 18, 2023 |title=Russia, Ukraine extend grain deal to aid world's poor |url=https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-grain-deal-black-sea-9b47d9d0b53e5ab0494c8eeea1197327 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230318145452/https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-grain-deal-black-sea-9b47d9d0b53e5ab0494c8eeea1197327 |archive-date=March 18, 2023 |access-date=March 18, 2023 |website=[[Associated Press]]}} On April 6 2023, Russian foreign minister [[Sergei Lavrov]] again visited [[Turkey]] to meet his counter-part [[Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu]]. Turkey served as a chief broker for the Black Sea Grain Initiative that opened up grain shipments from Ukraine and Russia to [[North Africa]] and the [[developing world]]. Russia has stated that sanctions impeded the export of Russian grain, and with the expiration of the deal, reduced Russian grain exports would accelerate inflation and food shortages. Because of intense diplomatic relations between Turkey and the [[Russian Federation]], a new deal would allow [[Ukraine]] to export another twenty-five million tons of grain and foodstuff to underdeveloped countries. Previously [[Western media]] had accused Lavrov of obstructing Ukrainian grain shipments.[https://www.foreignbrief.com/daily-news/russian-foreign-minister-sergei-lavrov-visits-turkey/ "Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov visits Turkey"] ''foreignbrief.com''. April 6, 2023. Accessed 13 April 2023.
